loan.use: To dig a well for family use, to fill up the land of her house's foundation and to purchase a motorbike for her daughter to get to work

loan.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Winnie has a retail shop business, which she has run for four years. She also sells charcoal.
To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Winnie hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. Winnie is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her an employment skill.

loan.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loan.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man M. (pictured here) and his wife have been married since 1980 and have five children - three sons and two daughters. Two are married and live outside the family home and the other three attend school.
Man is a fisherman. His wife sells the fish that her husband catches in the village. He is applying for his third loan of $450 to purchase a new boat motor because the one he currently has is old and does not work well.

loan.use: To purchase a new boat motor

loan.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Stella has a poultry business, which she has run for one year. She also has a retail shop.
To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase chicken feed and sugar. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Stella hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Stella hopes to become a nurse. Stella is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games.

loan.use: To purchase sugar for resale and chicken feed for her poultry business

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To purchase seed potatoes

loan.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Margret has a business selling shoes, which she has run for four years. She also sells charcoal.
To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal and shoes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further. Margret is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games.

loan.use: To purchase shoes and charcoal for resale

loan.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastula N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are currently in school. Mastula has a business selling food, which she has run for four years. She also sells vegetables.
To help expand her business, Mastula has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Mastula hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Mastula is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loan.use: To purchase more food for resale

loan.name: Phat

texts.en:
Mrs. Phat C. (pictured above), 35 years old, and her husband, Mr. Mao Rin, 36 years old, live in a small village along National Road Number Three about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have three children - two daughters and one son.
Phat has been selling noodles (kuyteav or ka tieu) in her village for almost 10 years. Kuyteav is the sound of the Khmer word for these noodles eaten with soup. Her husband assists his wife in the business. She is requesting her first loan of US$300 to buy a new motorcycle for commuting to replace the old one because it breaks down and uses more gasoline.

loan.use: To buy a new motorbike

loan.name: Rashidah

texts.en:
Rashidah N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. Rashidah has a dairy business, which she has run for one year.
To help expand her business, Rashidah has requested a loan of 100,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more milk. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rashidah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to sell charcoal. Rashidah is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loan.use: To purchase more milk for resale

loan.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma B. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 58 years old. Norma is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.
In 2010, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Bolormaa is a 34-year-old married woman who lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent on her sisterâ€™s plot of land, which is near her business place. They donâ€™t have any kids yet. Bolormaa operates a grocery store, selling items like meat and vegetables. She has been running this business for over three years and has a loyal customer base. Her husband helps her in the business and this is the only income for the family. She is planning to purchase her own plot of land and a wooden house with her savings.
Bolormaa is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase cheaper meat and vegetables to sell for a profit.

loan.use: to purchase cheaper meat and vegetables to sell for a profit.

loan.name: Pousary

texts.en:
Mr. Pousary L. and his wife, Mrs. Asimas Mat, have been married since 1991 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. The family lives about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Pousary is a fisherman and sells the fish that he catches to a middleman who comes to buy them at his house. His wife assists her husband in the business. Pousary requested a loan of $500 to purchase a boat motor and fishing supplies for his business.
Photo: Pousary with his wife and young son

loan.use: To purchase a boat motor and supplies for his fishing business.

loan.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is a dairy farmer in Murang'a town, central Kenya, where he has been farming for five years. He sells his milk through Kenya Co-operative Creameries. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to take care of the needs of his family.
He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the increased income from the sale of milk will help in the education of his children. In the future, he would like to improve his dairy farming and be able to produce at least 50 liters of milk daily.
Cyrus is 29 years old and married with two children, ages 4 and 7.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Ruth has a business selling clothes, which she has run for one year.
To help expand her business, Ruth has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Ruth hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a house. Ruth is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loan.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loan.name: Dany

texts.en:
Mrs. Dany K. (shown in the photo) is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Chantha Kem, is 38 years old. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1997 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two attend school and the other one is still young.
Dany sells clothes. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loan.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Christine has a business selling spare parts, which she has run for five years.
To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase spare parts. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Christine hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to get a good job. Christine is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by showing her how to interact with people.

loan.use: To purchase spare parts for resale

loan.name: Sopheak

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheak L. (pictured here) is 23 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Sokchea Sorm is 25 years old. They have been married since 2009 and have no children yet. They live with his parents and brothers and sisters along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Sopheak is a motorcycle taxi driver. His wife is a garment factory worker. He hopes to change his business from motorcycle taxi to Tuk Tuk (a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi), because it could carry more goods and people than a motorcycle taxi.
He asked for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a Tuk Tuk.

loan.use: To purchase a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi.

loan.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a farmer in Murang'a town in central Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for the past twenty years and employs one farmhand. His mixed farm produces milk and coffee which he sells locally. He also runs a small business in the same region.
He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will help improve the livelihood of his family. He plans to improve his dairy farming in the future by acquiring more dairy cows that will increase his income.
Joseph is 56 years old and married with four children who are all adults.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Wilma's Group

texts.en:
Wilma A. is from the village of Rizal West in San Isidro. She is 50 years old. Wilma is the group leader of a fourteen-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Wilma is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she manages a direct selling business, selling cosmetics and apparel products. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $69 a month for these activities.
In 2009, Wilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Pisey

texts.en:
Mrs. Pisey S. (shown in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Chanthorn Phon, live on an island in the Mekong River roughly 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2003. Mr. Chanthorn has a full time job in Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Pisey S. is a silk weaver. Besides selling her own silk products, she buys from other weavers in her village and resells to a middleman. She asked for another loan of $1,200 to continue her business by purchasing silk materials (raw silk) and buying silk fabric for resale.

loan.use: To purchase materials for her silk weaving business and to buy additional silk products for resale.

loan.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 19 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. Justine has a dry-cleaning business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase polythene jackets for keeping the clothes clean. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Justine hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Justine is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to work.

loan.use: To purchase polythene jackets to protect cleaned items of clothing

loan.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. Jenifer has a motorcycle(motor bike for transporting people) business, which she has run for three years. She also has a second business in selling clothes.
To help expand her business, Jenifer has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase motorcycle machines and clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jenifer hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Jenifer is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by assisting her in improving her business.

loan.use: To purchase motorcycle machines and clothes

loan.name: Gerelmaa

texts.en:
Gerelmaa is 29 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her eldest two children attend a local secondary school and the youngest son stays at home. She rents a stall at the market where she sells fruits and vegetables. She has been running this business since 2005. She has used her earnings to provide for her children and to pay their living expenses.
Her husband Altanshagai, 27 years old, helps her business with his microbus by transporting her products to the market. In the future she is planning to increase her working capital and to give her children a good education and morals.
She is applying for a loan for 900,000 MNT to purchase fruits and vegetables at wholesale prices to resell to her many customers.

loan.use: to increase her inventory

loan.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira K. is the leader of this group. She is 37 years old and married. Her husband works in Russia. Gulmira herself takes care of four children: three daughters and a son. All the children study at school. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Gulmira breeds livestock and then resells at a higher price after fattening them. In this way she earns about $65 per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future Gulmira wants to provide her children with a good education.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line â€“ People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase cattle

loan.name: Hajara

texts.en:
Hajara N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 1 child. None of her children is currently in school. Hajara has a business of a salon, which she has had for 3 years. She also has a second business of a drug shop.
To help expand her business, Hajara has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase braids for her salon. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hajara hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Hajara hopes to become a nurse. Hajara is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her job skills.

loan.use: To purchase braids for her salon

loan.name: Berson

texts.en:
Berson has been in the farming business for the last fifteen years. His mixed farm, which is located in Kisii town in western Kenya, produces tea, bananas and maize which he sells locally. He employs four farmhands.
He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to expand his cereals store. He says that the extra income from this loan will be used to expand his farming. He faces the challenges of a poor road network to the market and insufficient funds for expansion. In the future he would like to buy a piece of land to build some rental houses that will supplement his income.
Berson is 44 years old and married with six children between the ages of 6 months and 16 years. Four of the children are currently attending school.

loan.use: To expand his cereals store

loan.name: Naume

texts.en:
Naume B. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala. She is single and has no children. Naume has a business of selling fruits and vegetables, which she has had for 1 year. She also has a second business of outside catering.
To help expand her business, Naume has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase vegetables, Irish and cooking oil. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Naume hopes to generate greater profits and taking care of herself. In the future, Naume hopes to study hair dressing. Naume is a member of BRACâ€™s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by knowing how to sing and dance.

loan.use: To purchase vegetables and oil for resale

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase sugar and charcoal for resale

loan.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun S. is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Sophara Chhom, is 32 years old. They are pictured here together. They live in a village approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1994 and have one young daughter.
Saroeun sells sewing machines. Her husband is a sewing machine repairman and works along with his wifeâ€™s business.
Saroeun hopes to expand her business by purchasing additional sewing machines for resale, so she is applying for her first loan of $1,000.

loan.use: To expand her business.

loan.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a farmer in Kisii town in western Kenya where he has been farming for the last twenty years. His mixed farm produces coffee, maize, beans and milk which are all sold locally. He also depends on his pension pay to meet the needs of his family.
He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help pay school fees for his children and improve the livelihood of his family. In five years' time, he hopes to have a cooling plant and to improve his milk production.
Stephen is 65 years old and married with five children who are all adults. One of his children is still attending school.

loan.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loan.name: Cirilo

texts.en:
Cirilo G. is from the village of District 4 in San Manuel, Isabela. He is 46 years old. Cirilo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $230 a month for these activities.
In 2010, Cirilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Jane Muthoni

texts.en:
Jane Muthoni K. is 40 years old and married to Daniel. They have two children. For the past 11 years, Jane has been operating a restaurant in Githurai 45 from which she earns a monthly profit of 35,000 KES.
Jane is requesting a loan of 80,000 KES to purchase food stock as well as buy a few tables and chairs to increase her cash flow. This is her first loan with KADET LTD. She plans to save her profit from the loan to purchase a plot of land and build a hotel. In the future, Jane dreams of owning a big hotel with a swimming pool and educating her children.

loan.use: to purchase food stock and tables and chairs

loan.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mrs. Vannak Y. is 30 years old and her husband, Mr. Thearith Chan, is 28 years old. They live in a village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2007 and have one young son.
Vannak and her husband are farmers and raise pigs. When free, Vannak also sells vegetables, and her husband drives a motor taxi.
She is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase feed for the pigs and to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.
Photo: Mrs. Vannak Y. and her husband

loan.use: To purchase feed for the pigs and to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

loan.name: Sobirahon's Group

texts.en:
Sobirahon A. is the leader of this group. She is 51 years old and divorced. She has two sons and two daughters. The older son works in construction, the second provides auto repair services, and the daughters study at the university.
In order to earn money, Sobirahon breeds cattle and then resells them at a higher price after fattening. In this way she earns about $85 per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two bull calves for breeding.
In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and save money to celebrate her daughterâ€™s wedding.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line â€“ People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.
To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase two bull calves

loan.name: Savoen

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoen H. (shown in the photo) is 29 years old, and her husband, Mr. Samonn Y, is 30 years old. They live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2005 and have one young daughter.
Savoen sells groceries at home. Her husband is a goldsmith. She is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to build her own house to live in because she is currently staying with her parents.

loan.use: To build her own house to live in

loan.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel has been practicing mixed farming for the last twenty years in Kisii town in western Kenya. His mixed farm produces maize, millet, cabbages and milk, which are all sold locally. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to meet the basic needs of his family.
He recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES and has requested this loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He hopes that this dairy cow will improve his milk production and that he will be able to provide his family with enough milk for both domestic consumption and sale. His major challenges have been poor weather conditions and low market prices for his products. He would like to acquire a motorbike in the future that will assist him in the transportation of his products to the market.
Samuel is 58 years old and married with 18 children who are between the ages of 5 and 30. Sixteen of the children are attending school.

loan.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loan.name: Ser

texts.en:
Mr. Ser Y. (shown in the photo) is 40 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Thyda Tep, is 31 years old. They live along national road number six about ten kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two daughters.
Ser is a mechanic. His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to renovate the house where he lives.

loan.use: To renovate the house where he lives.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family and four siblings. He works with his brothers to meet the familyâ€™s financiA. target. He has been working in the agriculturA. field for 10 years and bought his own land in 2006. His work consists of cultivating the land to produce vegetables and selling them in the north of Lebanon.
Today, he is asking to borrow $800 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additionA. agriculturA. materials and tools to improve his productivity and; therefore, his sales and profitability.

loan.use: To purchase additional agriculture materials and tools

loan.name: Simon

texts.en:
Mrs. Simon T. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Nhel, live in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1979 and have six children: two sons and four daughters.
Simon is a rice farmer. Her husband is a truck driver; he purchases and hauls dirt to sell to villagers for leveling their house foundations. Simon is asking for a loan of $500 to expand her husband's business of purchasing and hauling dirt to sell for leveling house foundations.

loan.use: To expand business of selling dirt for leveling house foundations

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He has been working in agriculture for more than 12 years. In 2000, he purchased his own private land and started cultivating it to produce vegetables. He sells his produce in his town and surrounding areas.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to get essential tools to improve his work and increase his productivity and sales.

loan.use: To buy essential tools

loan.name: Sovan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovan P. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Savuth Chim, live in a Phnom Penh suburb. They were married in 1985 and have two children: one son and one daughter.
Sovan is a rice farmer. She sells dessert in Oreusey market located in Phnom Penh when she is not at the farm. She is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to build a fence around her house.

loan.use: To build a fence

loan.name: Channy

texts.en:
Mrs. Channy C. (pictured with her husband) is 22 years old. Her husband, Mr. Sineth Chhan, is 27 years old. They live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2008 and have one young son.
Channy and her husband are vegetable farmers. They grow cabbage and beans on their farmland in the village where they live. Channy is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain her vegetable farm.

loan.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, and pesticide

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and two children. He is the only financiA. support for his family. He has 10 years of experience in car maintenance and painting and opened his own garage in 2005. Through the years, he has built a good business reputation.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase extra products for his garage to provide better service for his clients so he can make more profit.

loan.use: To purchase extra products for his garage

loan.name: Mukarramhon's Group

texts.en:
Mukarramhon U. is the treasurer of this group. She is 44 years old and married. She has two sons and a daughter. Her first son works in construction, and the other children are in school. Mukarramhon and her husband breed cattle. The family earns 3000 KGS per month by reselling cattle after fattening. That profit made it possible for them to save money and make some house repairs. With money received from the loan the family wants to purchase a bull calf for breeding. In the future, Mukarramhon wants to see her children get married.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line â€“ People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase a bull calf

loan.name: Benson

texts.en:
From the town of Nkubu in eastern Kenya, 41-year-old Benson M. has been practicing mixed farming for the past ten years. His main products are potatoes, french beans, maize and milk which are all sold to middlemen. Farming is his main source of income.

Benson has requested this loan of 47,250KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this cow will improve his milk production, ensuring that his family will have enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The additional income resulting from this loan will enable Benson to pay school fees for his children. In five years' time, he hopes to have expanded his dairy farming by acquiring four more dairy cows. His major challenges have been a lack of market for his products, the high cost of pesticides and poor weather conditions.

Benson is married with three children between the ages of 2 and 11, two of whom are currently attending school.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 40-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and four children. He and his wife both work to satisfy the familyâ€™s needs. His wife works in a local agriculture center. He has 25 years of experience in the concrete field and began to operate his business as a freelance concrete worker in 1995. He works on customer demand. He obtained his first Kiva loan with a successful outcome.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase some wood to make his concrete work stronger. In the future, he hopes to continue the growth of his business and to be able to take on some construction projects in order to expand his business operation.

loan.use: To purchase some wood to make his concrete work stronger

loan.name: Pacita Santos Group

texts.en: Pacita S. is from the village of Punit. She is 51 years old and is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Pacita S.. Pacita is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Pacita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Pacita has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Pacita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pacita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Pacita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Pacita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Benson Kanene

texts.en:
Benson Kanene K. is 25 years old and single. He is a hardworking man. He has operated a retail shop in Babadogo for eight years with income of 7,100 KES per month.
He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and he has never borrowed from any other MFI. Benson's first loan of 20,000 KES will be used to add more stock, such as rice, flour, cooking fat, flour, and soap. The anticipated profit will be reinvested into the business by purchasing additional stock because customers are attracted by a well stocked shop. In the future he hopes to own a supermarket.

loan.use: To purchase stock of items, e.g., rice, flour, cooking oil, soaps

loan.name: Anna Leah

texts.en: Anna Leah M. is from the village of Ponce St., Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Anna Leah owns and operates a business providing internet services in the local community. Anna Leah has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Anna Leah joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anna Leah is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anna Leah from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loan.name: Eunice Ene

texts.en:
Eunice is 23 years old and married to Manbui Mereu. They have three children. For the past three years, Eunice has been rearing animals to sell in Naivasha town.
Eunice was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan to buy 15 young goats which she will rear and later sell at a profit. In the future, Eunice hopes to practice dairy farming to diversify and increase her income.

loan.use: to buy goats

loan.name: John Njoroge

texts.en:
John Njoroge K. is 35 years old, married, and has five children. He has practiced farming in Njabini town for the last 13 years.
He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He repaid all his previous loans and in good time. He plans to use the loan to buy potato seedlings and manure for the farm. In the future, John hopes to buy his own piece of land where he will be continue farming.

loan.use: To purchase potato seedlings and manure for the farm

loan.name: Onduso

texts.en:
Onduso is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya where he has been farming for over 8 years. His mixed farm produces milk, maize, beans and bananas which are all sold locally. He also earns income from his kiosk which he operates in the same location.
He recently repaid his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 40,000 KES and has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that this loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase his milk production. The extra income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children.
Onduso is 27 years old and married with children ages 2 and 4.

loan.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loan.name: Lazarus Mungora

texts.en: Lazarus, who is 34 years old, married to Dorcas Wangui and the father of two children, has operated a motorcycle transport business in Naivasha town for the last two years. He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, and this will be his first loan which he will use to renew the insurance on his motorbike. In the future, Lazarus hopes to grow his business and buy his own lorry.

loan.use: To renew insurance forhis motorbike.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He has been working as a fisherman for over 12 years and has had his own fishing boat since 2002. He buys tools from a local fishing center to support his business operation.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase fishing equipment and supplies and to make much needed repairs to his fishing boat. These improvements will make his fishing operation more secure â€“ especially in disturbing weather. In the future, he would like to purchase another boat. He feels positive about his business prospects for the coming year.

loan.use: To purchase fishing equipment and supplies and to make repairs to his fishing boat

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single woman. She is from Lebanon and lives with her parents and two siblings. She and her father are the sole income providers for the family. Her father works in the agricultural field. She wants to increase her familyâ€™s profit. She has been working as a hairdresser for 10 years and, in 2006, she decided to open her own salon.
Today, she is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to upgrade her salon tools and purchase vaporization machinery. She wants to offer a comfortable service to her clients and increase her income.

loan.use: To upgrade her salon tools and purchase vaporization machinery

loan.name: Ednita

texts.en: Ednita R. is from the village of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old, separated from her spouse and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ednita owns and operate a direct-sales business selling personal products such as glasses and watches in the local community. Ednita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Ednita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ednita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ednita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is a farmer from Nyamira town in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for twenty years and employs 10 casual laborers. His main products are tea, which he sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority, milk, maize, beans and eggs which he sells locally. Farming is his only source of income.
He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family. His major challenges have been lack of enough farm inputs (fertilisers, etc.), pests, diseases and poor weather conditions which affect his production. In five years time, he hopes to acquire a truck that will assist in the transportation of his products to the market.
Samwel is 39 years old and married with 6 children who are now between the ages of 2 and 18. All the children, except one, attend school.

loan.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loan.name: Risa Ole

texts.en: Risa, 22 years of age, has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last six years. He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy more sheep and goats to rear and later sell at a profit. In the future, Risa hopes to practice zero-grazing, which is easier to manage.

loan.use: To buy more sheep and goats to rear and sell later at a profit.

loan.name: Davaasuren

texts.en:
Davaasuren B. is 28 years old, married and the mother of two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on her mother-in-law's plot of land. Her elder son, Bilguun, 7, attends a local secondary school and her younger son, Chinguun, 1, stays at home. Her husband, Mandaakhuu, 32, operates a taxi in the city.
Davaasuren has recently been operating a restroom service business at the bus station. She used her earnings to purchase a second-hand car in fair condition.
She is planning to purchase her own plot of land with a wooden house and to provide for the necessary expenses for her children. Davaasuren is requesting a loan to purchase a computer and some spare parts for her family car.

loan.use: To purchase a computer and some spare parts for her family car

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She is living with her parents and three siblings. She has two years of experience working with mobile phones. She sells rechargeable phone cards from her house. She has been working hard to support her family in cooperation with her parents.
Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to increase her merchandise selection and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell. Most mobile phone users in Lebanon purchase these prepaid cards; it is less common to have an annual phone contract. In the future, she hopes to enlarge her business and own her own phone shop.

loan.use: To increase her merchandise selection and purchase prepaid telephone cards

loan.name: Pauline Nateleng

texts.en:
Pauline Nateleng L. is 29 years old and has been selling fruits and vegetables in Naivasha market for the last two years.
She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her second loan. She repaid her first loan of 25,000 KES in good time. She plans to use this loan to buy potatoes, carrots, and onions to sell.
In the future, Pauline hopes to be selling fruits and vegetables in large quantities, buying the produce directly from the farmers, and selling to the local retailers.

loan.use: To purchase potatoes, carrots, and onions

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and four siblings. He helps his brothers to maintain a good income for the family. Despite his young age, he has been working as a freelance electrician specializing in electric projects for four years. He obtained a first Kiva loan and was a very good client with payments on time.
Today, he is requesting a larger loan of $1500 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to renew his tools so he can improve his work and take on bigger projects in his community.

loan.use: To renew his tools

loan.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah K. is 31 years old and married with four children who all attend school.
She has a mixed farm in Kisii town, western Kenya, that produces maize, beans, cabbages, tomatoes and carrots, which she sells locally. She has been in the farming business for more than 20 years. Her primary challenges are diseases and price fluctuations. She depends mainly on the income from her farm to meet the basic needs of her family.
Zipporah has requested a loan of 35000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to improve her zero-grazing (stall-feeding) farming. The extra income from this loan will help pay school fees for her children. In the future, she would like to own at least two quality dairy cows.

loan.use: To improve her livestock farming

loan.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio A. is from the village of District 4. He is 53 years old. Antonio is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Antonio raises crops, primarily rice, for sale. Antonio has been engaged in his business for more than 23 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.
In 2010, Antonio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Antonio is requesting a loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken by Antonio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business.
About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and three young children, who are attending school. She helps her husband to satisfy the family's income needs. Her husband sells car spare parts. Since 2004, she's owned a clothes store, buying her products from a local clothing center. She always tries to be up-to-date with the market and new designs to attract a good number of clients.
Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additional products for her store so that she can gratify her customers.

loan.use: To purchase additional products for her store

loan.name: Josphat Gichumu

texts.en:
Josphat Gichumu G. is 58 years old, married, and has three children. He has been making metal products in Naivasha town for the last 14 years.
He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan of 25,000 KES in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy raw materials for his metal workshop.
In the future, Josphat hopes to open a big workshop and be able to make his products in large quantities.

loan.use: To purchase raw materials for his metal workshop.

loan.name: Satyndy's Group

texts.en:
Satyndy T., 48, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Balykchi, a small town in the Isykul region. She is married to a driver. Together they are bringing up two sons and two daughters. Satyndy herself works as a nurse in the hospital. Her monthly salary is 2000 KGS.
Her older son is a truck driver who earns money by transporting goods. She applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for her younger sonâ€™s education at university. In the future she wants to see her children married.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To pay for her son's education

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man living with his wife and two school-age children. He is from Lebanon. He is the only income source for his family. He started to work as a car mechanic ten years ago. After seeing a need for this service in his town, he decided to open his own garage in 2006. He obtained his first Kiva loan and has been a punctual client with prompt payments.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to get diverse tools for his garage so he can guarantee his customers a much better service.

loan.use: To get diverse tools for his garage

loan.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah J. is 32 years old and married with four children who all attend school. She has been in the farming business for ten years. Her mixed farm, which is located in Kisii town, western Kenya, produces onions, vegetables, maize, beans, bananas and milk, which are all sold locally. She also runs a food kiosk in the same region.
Sarah's major challenges have been diseases and the high cost of veterinary services. She has requested a loan of 45000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help improve the living standard of her family.
Sarah aspires to acquire a vehicle in the future that will assist in the transportation of her products to the local market.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Gulnaz's Group

texts.en:
Gulnaz J., the 38-year-old leader of this group, resides in Balykchi, a small town in Isykul region. Married to a taxi driver who earns 5000 soms per month, Gulnaz and he are the parents of a son and two daughters. The daughters study at school and the son works in a private enterprise that produces plastic windows. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Gulnaz sells apples, buying them at a low price in the village and then reselling them in the city for an income of about 20000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Gulnaz wants to purchase more apples for sale.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line â€“ People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase apples

loan.name: Esinyen

texts.en:
Esinyen E. is 39 years old, married, and has two children. He has operated his retail shop in Naivasha town since 2005.
He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan of 20,000 KES in good time. He plans to use the loan to buy dry foodstuff for sell in his shop.
In the future, Esinyen hopes to grow his retail shop to a mini supermarket.

loan.use: To purchase dry foodstuff for his shop

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and one sibling. She helps her father assure the family has a good income. She has been growing tobacco for 15 years and in 2000, she bought land so she could produce tobacco and sell it to her own customers.
Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase needed products to make her tobacco cultivation easier and faster.

loan.use: To purchase supplies

loan.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a farmer from Nyamira town in western Kenya. He has been farming for the last 25 years and employs two farmhands. His main products are maize and tea, which he sells locally. He is also in the business of buying and selling cows at a local market.
He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children. In the future, he plans to own a posho (cornmeal) mill that will help supplement his income. His biggest challenge has been low prices for his products, especially tea.
Joseph is 52 years old and married with seven children who are now between the ages of 13 and 33. Two of his children are currently attending school.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings. He is from Lebanon. He worked in a barber shop for six years and opened his own shop in 2008. In addition to his brotherâ€™s and fatherâ€™s income, he is also considered to be an income provider for the family. He obtained a first Kiva loan and was an excellent client with punctual payments.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to enlarge his business. He will buy more products and tools for his shop so he can satisfy his customers' needs and get higher revenue.

loan.use: To enlarge his business

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and one child. He is the only income source for his family. For 8 years, he has worked as a furniture painter and, in 2004, he started his furniture painting shop. He works closely with locA. galleries in his town. He obtained a first Kiva loan and was a very good client with payments on time.
Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase more equipment for his painting shop. He wants to enlarge his business so he can work on various types of furniture.

loan.use: To purchase equipment

loan.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya where he has been farming for 10 years. His farm produces maize, beans and bananas, which are all sold locally. He also operates a shop and a hotel business in the same region.
He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family. His major challenge has been the high cost of farm inputs, which affects his production. In the future, he would like to acquire more land to enable him to expand his farming activities.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman living with her husband and two young children, who are still attending school. She is from Lebanon. She helps her husband, a tailor, with the familyâ€™s income. She started a lingerie and accessories shop in 2008, after nine years of experience in this field.
Today, she is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to increase her inventory so she can offer her clients new and different styles. She is confident that her work will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loan.use: To increase her inventory

loan.name: Sairakul's Group

texts.en:
Sairakul U. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Bokonbaevo, a nice village in the Isykul region. She is 56 and married to a doctor. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 soms, Sairakul and her husband started to breed cattle. Reselling cattle after fattening earns 2,000 soms per month for the family. Sairakul applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for her sonâ€™s education at the university. In the future, she wants to increase the number of cattle to be able to support her son financially.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line â€“ People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan â€“ Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to pay for her son's education

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To repaint his van and perform the necessary maintenance

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Pacifica

texts.en:
Pacifica A. is 50 years old and married with seven children who are now between the ages of 15 and 25. One of the children attends school.
Pacifica is a farmer in Nyamira town in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces vegetables, maize, beans, tea and milk, which are sold locally. She also earns income from her business of selling snacks to the local market.
She has requested this loan of 45000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the living standard of the family.
In the future, she would like to buy a vehicle that will assist her in transporting her products to the market.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald O. is 30 years old and married with two children, ages 3 and 5, who both attend school. He has a mixed farm that produces bananas, maize and beans, which are all sold to the local market. He has been in the farming business for four years and employs two farmhands. He also earns income from his hotel and tailoring businesses in the same region. His biggest challenges have been lack of enough farm inputs (such as fertilizer) and too much rain, which affects his production.
He has requested this loan of 45000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this dairy cow will improve his milk production and that his family will have enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. He is hopeful that his farming will expand in the future and that he will be able to sell his products wholesale.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Los Mosqueteros Group

texts.es: El banco comunal â€œLos Mosqueterosâ€ es conformado por 17 emprendedores pertenecientes a la ciudad de ViÃ±a del Mar. Sus principales negocios son de confecciÃ³n, venta de provisiones, ropa, carteras, producciÃ³n y venta de joyas artesanales y comida rÃ¡pida. MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica es la presidenta de este grupo, en la foto se encuentra en la Ãºltima fila, en 1Âº lugar de izquierda a derecha. Su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa de casa, como por ejemplo: cortinas, sÃ¡banas, cobertores, plumones, manteles, etc., a domicilio y por encargos, desde hace 3 aÃ±os. Con este prÃ©stamo, y gracias a sus ahorros, este mes comenzarÃ¡ un nuevo negocio, ademÃ¡s del que ya tiene. Se iniciarÃ¡ con la venta de frutas y verduras, naturales y congeladas en su casa. Su sueÃ±o es tener una tienda de artÃ­culos para el hogar, establecida en el centro de la ciudad. Su motivaciÃ³n son sus 3 hijos: su hija de 20 aÃ±os, quien estudia fonoaudiologÃ­a en la universidad; su hijo de 16, quien le ayudarÃ¡ con la venta de verduras y su pequeÃ±a de 10 aÃ±os. Para MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica, Fondo Esperanza ha sido un gran apoyo, no solo econÃ³mico, sino tambiÃ©n en la capacitaciÃ³n para administrar bien su negocio. ViÃ±a del Mar es una ciudad y comuna ubicada en el litoral central de Chile, conocida como la Ciudad JardÃ­n debido a los jardines y patios que poseen algunas viviendas antiguas de la ciudad. TambiÃ©n es considerada la capital turÃ­stica de Chile.
texts.en:
â€œLos Mosqueterosâ€ (The Musketeers) community bank has 17 entrepreneurial members who live in the city of ViÃ±a del Mar. Their main business activities are dressmaking, selling provisions, clothes, purses, making and selling hand-crafted jewelry and selling fast food.
MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica is the president of this group. In the photo she is on the far left in the back row. Her business is selling household linen such as, for example: drapes, sheets, bedspreads, quilts, tablecloths, etc. She sells her goods door to door and to order. She has been in this business for 3 years.
Thanks to this loan and some savings she has, MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica will set up a new business this month in addition to the one she already has. She will start selling fresh and frozen fruit and vegetables from her home.
MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica's dream is to own a store where she can sell household items in the city center. Her motivation comes from her 3 children: her 20 year-old daughter who is studying speech and language pathology at university, her 16 year-old son, who will help her with her vegetable sales and her 10 year-old daughter.
For MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica, Fondo Esperanza has been a great support, not only economically but also through their training sessions which teach members how to run their businesses.
ViÃ±a del Mar is a city and municipality on the central Chilean coast. It is known as 'The Garden City' owing to the gardens and courtyards that some of the old houses in the city have. It is also considered the tourist capital of Chile.

loan.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Los Gemelos Group

texts.es: Marco forma parte del banco comunal â€œLos Gemelosâ€ conformado por 21 emprendedores pertenecientes a la comuna de MaipÃº. En la foto se encuentra al centro y usa un gorro blanco y sus lentes encima. El negocio de Marco consiste en la elaboraciÃ³n y venta de productos de panaderÃ­a y pastelerÃ­a en su casa, desde hace mÃ¡s de 2 aÃ±os. TambiÃ©n hace 4 meses, se dedica a la venta de helados de mÃ¡quina, ya que la venta de los productos de panaderÃ­a disminuye en el tiempo de calor. Marco comenzÃ³ con su negocio independiente, cuando se dio cuenta, por su experiencia laboral, que el trabajo de panadero no es muy conveniente. Su esposa, quien tambiÃ©n trabaja con Fondo Esperanza, lo apoya en el negocio. Con este prÃ©stamo comprarÃ¡ mezclas para los helados y barquillos. Su sueÃ±o es tener una amasanderÃ­a. Tiene dos hijos: un niÃ±o de 11 aÃ±os y una pequeÃ±a de 5 aÃ±os. A Marco lo que mÃ¡s le gusta de Fondo Esperanza es la oportunidad que le dan a los emprendedores, cuando les entregan los prÃ©stamos, para salir adelante con sus negocios. AdemÃ¡s para Ã©l los crÃ©ditos han sido un gran apoyo para mantener su negocio. MaipÃº es una comuna ubicada al este de Santiago, capital de Chile, regiÃ³n Metropolitana. Designada como la comuna mÃ¡s grande de Chile es llamada Cuna de la Patria debido a importantes hechos histÃ³ricos ocurridos en esas tierras durante la Ã©poca de la Independencia, como la Batalla y el Abrazo de MaipÃº entre los libertadores de Chile Bernardo OÂ´Higgins y Argentina, San MartÃ­n.
texts.en:
Marco is part of the "Los Gemelos" (Twins) community bank which has 21 entrepreneurial members who live in the town of MaipÃº. In the photo, Marco is in the middle wearing a white cap with sunglasses on top.
Marco's business is making and selling bakery and confectionery products in his home. He has been doing this for more than 2 years. He has also been selling ice cream from an ice cream machine since sales of his baked products fall during the hot weather. Marco started his own business when he realized, through his own work experience, that a baker's work isn't very convenient. His wife, who also works with Fondo Esperanza, supports him in his business.
He will use his loan to buy mix for his ice creams and cones. His dream is to own an 'amasanderia' (a type of Chilean bakery). Marco has two children: an 11 year-old boy and a 5 year-old girl. What Marco most likes about Fondo Esperanza is the opportunity that they give entrepreneurs when they provide them with loans to get ahead in their businesses. Also, the loans have been a great support to him in keeping his business running.
MaipÃº is a town located to the east of Santiago, capital of Chile, in the Metropolitan region. Designed as the biggest town in Chile it is called the 'Birthplace of the Nation' owing to the important historic events that have taken place on these lands during the Independence period such as the Battle and Embrace of MaipÃº between the liberators of Chile, Bernardo O'Higgins, and Argentina, San MartÃ­n.

loan.use: Mix for ice cream and cones

loan.name: Umurava Group

texts.en:
Alphonsine is 45 years old and married to a farmer. They have eight children who are between 3 and 22 years old. Alponsine is a group leader of a borrowing group called Umurava CB, which means "Determination" in English.
Alphonsine sells juice locally produced from sorghum and she has been in this business for three years. She has requested this loan to buy more sorghum to produce more liters of local juice to sell. She says that the profits from this business will be used to buy land for cultivation and pay school fees for her children. She dreams of having her own shop in the future.

loan.use: To buy more sorghum to produce more local juice to sell

loan.name: Protais

texts.en:
Protais is 55 years old and married to a farmer. They have eight children who are between 15 and 25 years old. All his children go to school.
Protais owns a business selling a large variety of goods. With this loan, he will add more merchandise such as sugar, sodas, rice, potatoes, eggs and tea to sell. He hopes to use the profit from this business to pay school fees for his children, make savings and build a house. Protais' plan is to work hard and in the future become a wholesaler.

loan.use: To buy more items to resell

loan.name: Eric

texts.en: Eric sells clothes. He is 31 years old, married, and has two children who are three and six years old. His wife is a businessperson. Eric has been selling clothes for 10 years, and he plans to use his loan to stock more clothes to sell. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to renovate his house.

loan.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loan.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is forty years old, a widow and has one child who attends school. Josephine sells shoes and clothes for women, especially jackets and T-shirts. She has been in business for one year.

Josephine is requesting a loan to purchase more shoes and clothes. With the new profits from her expanded business, Josephine plans to pay school fees for her children and reinvest to continue to grow her business.

loan.use: To buy more used clothes and shoes to sell

loan.name: Pierrine

texts.en:
Pierrine is thirty years old, married and has one child. Her husband works as a businessperson. Pierrine sells clothes, especially bed covers and bed sheets, which she has been doing for five years.

Pierrine is requesting a loan to buy more bed covers and bed sheets to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Pierrine plans to reinvest and increase her working capital.

loan.use: To buy more bed covers and bed sheets to sell

loan.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 29 years old, married and has three children between the ages of five and fourteen. Her husband is a businessperson as well.

Odette has been selling charcoal for eight years. Her loan will be used to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell. She hopes to reinvest all new profits and continue to improve her business.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loan.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 35 years old, married and has four children who are between six and fourteen years old. All of her children go to school. Her husband is a businessman.

Claudine has been selling a variety of items from her own boutique for six years. Her loan will be used to purchase more merchandise to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build her own store in the future.

loan.use: To buy more items to sell

loan.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson K. is 60 years old and a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya where he has been farming for 35 years. His main products are milk, chickens, bananas, maize, and tea, which he sells at the local market and through the Kenya Tea Development Authority. He also depends on his pension pay to cater to the needs of his family. His major challenges in farming have been unpredictable weather conditions and poor market prices for his products.
He has requested a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that he will be able to acquire another asset for his family and that they will also be able to get enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. He plans to venture into transport business in the future.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Resiato Ene

texts.en: Resiato has been raising animals to sell in Naivasha town for the last year. She is 23 years old, married to Jackson K. and they have two children. She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use it to buy 10 young goats and 15 lambs which she will raise and sell later at a profit. In the future, Resiato hopes to practice large-scale livestock farming.

loan.use: To buy 10 young goats and 15 lambs which she will raise and sell later at a profit.

loan.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is 28 years old and married with two children ages three and six. For the past nine years, he has been in the farming business. Jacksonâ€™s mixed farm is located in Kisii town, western Kenya, and he produces maize, beans, onions, and millet all of which are sold locally.
Jackson is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to improve his farm and pay school fees for his children. Jacksonâ€™s major business challenges have been poor weather conditions, pests, diseases and the lack of markets for his products. In the future, Jackson plans to open a retail shop and expand his farm by leasing more land.

loan.use: to purchase a cow

loan.name: Jefferson

texts.en:
Jefferson is 43 years old and married with six children between the ages of two and 26. Four of his children are currently attending school. Jefferson is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya where he has been farming for twenty six years. His mixed farm produces maize, beans, millet, tea, milk and bananas which are all sold locally. Jefferson also earns income from trading cattle.
Jefferson is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes that his family will now eat well since he will have enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. Jefferson also says that his asset base will increase with the purchase of another dairy cow. In future, Jefferson plans to open a big retail shop at a local market.

loan.use: to purchase a cow

loan.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 50 years old and married with eight children who are between the ages of eight and 33. Two of her children are currently attending school. For the past 32 years, Josephine has been practicing mixed farming and she employs four farmhands. Her mixed farm is located in Kisii town, western Kenya, and she produces maize, millet, milk, tea and nappier grass which she sells locally. Farming is her main source of income.
Josephine is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her pay school fees for her children. Josephineâ€™s primary business challenges have been poor weather conditions, pests and diseases, and fluctuation in the market prices of her farm products. In the future, Josephine plans to expand her farm and purchase a posho mill to grind flour to supplement her income.

loan.use: to purchase a cow

loan.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert M. is 62 years old, married, and has six adult children. He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya and has been in the farming business for over 30 years. He employs three casual laborers. Robert sells his farm products at the local market. He also earns income from his posho mill in the same region.
Robert has requested a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable his family to meet their basic needs and improve their livelihood. He plans to acquire more land in the future that will enable him expand his farming activities. He faces the challenges of drought, which affects his production, and bad debtors, which affects his cash flow.
